The geometric and electronic structure of Pt active sites plays a crucial role in determining the catalysts performance, but precise regulation remains challenging. Herein, we propose a novel approach to modulate the nature of Pt active sites by combining photo-deposition of Pt nanoparticles with ultra-low Mo loading (0.1 wt%) modification on Pt/SiO2 catalysts. The addition of ultra-low loading Mo promoter not only effectively reduces the size of Pt particles but also donates electrons to the Pt particles. Furthermore, the photo-deposited Pt particles exhibit a higher proportion of metallic Pt species, which is more stable than that metallic Pt species obtained by H2 reduction, compared to those prepared using traditional wetness impregnation methods. Propane oxidation activity evaluations confirm that the photo-deposited and Mo-modified Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst exhibits the highest activity among all the prepared catalysts. Combined with experiments of C3H8-TPSR and in-situ DRIFT spectra of propane oxidation, it is found that the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst remarkably promotes propane activation and C-H bond cleavage due to the nature change of Pt active sites, and the presence of gaseous oxygen benefits propane cleavage on active sites. Our primary results provide a promising strategy for designing superior platinum catalysts by regulating Pt active sites nature for efficient propane complete oxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Propane complete oxidation Pt catalyst Ultra-low loading Mo promoter Pt active sites Photo-deposition of Pt nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission has increasingly drawn significant attention because most VOCs are very toxic which seriously do harm to both the ecological environment and human health, and also contribute to production of ground-level ozone and photochemical smog [1–3]. Numerous technologies are developed for VOCs emission abatement due to the strict environmental legislation, such as non-destructive methods of adsorption, absorption, condensation and membrane separation, and destructive methods of thermal combustion, catalytic combustion, low-temperature plasma, etc [4,5]. Among them, catalytic combustion has received significant attention, owning to its high efficiency dealing with dilute VOC (<0.5 vol%) into harmless CO2 and H2O [6–9]. The efficiency of catalytic combustion is mainly determined by the kind of VOC and the choice of catalyst. Of the most stable VOCs, it is widely recognized that light alkane VOC (such as propane) is removed with great difficulty, which usually require noble metal based catalyst and high operation temperature [10–12]. Much work so far has focused on propane catalytic oxidation because of propane as the primary component of liquefied petroleum gas released to the atmosphere, and propane with complex geometry representative to larger saturated alkanes. Both non-noble metal based catalysts (Co3O4, MnOx, etc) [13,14] and noble metal based catalysts (Pt, Pd, Ru) [15–18] are widely employed to catalyze propane oxidation. It is generally accepted that Pt based catalyst, with robust thermal stability and high activity, is the most efficient for propane catalytic oxidation. Considerable research efforts have been devoted to developing active catalyst to save noble metal for propane oxidation due to scarcity and high prices of noble metal. It is commonly recognized that supports and additives would significantly affect the catalytic performance of Pt catalyst for propane oxidation because the nature of Pt species remarkably changes when different support or additives used [19–21]. For propane oxidation over Pt catalyst, most previous works agreed that metallic Pt specie is active for initial C-H bond activation and break, and oxidized Pt specie enables the further oxidation of activated hydrocarbons [22,23]. Thus, catalytic performance of Pt catalyst is usually determined by the nature of Pt species (particle size, geometric shape, and surface Pt species valence state). Supports used for loading Pt catalyst for propane oxidation mainly include silicon aluminum zeolites (ZSM-5, USY, HY, etc.) [24] and metal oxides (CeO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2-ZrO2, etc.) [25,26]. Pt loaded on support with abundant acidic sites on the surface exhibits superior oxidation activity towards alkane VOCs compared to that on weakly acidic or alkaline support, owing to acidic support stabilizing metallic Pt species under oxidation condition [27–29]. Previous works found that transition metal oxides (WO3, MoO3, Nb2O5, V2O5, FeOx) [30–32] additive significantly promotes propane oxidation activity of Pt catalysts, most works ascribed it to generation of more metallic Pt species. Our group believed that formation of new highly active sites (such as Pt-WO3 and Pt-MoO3 interface sites) accounts for the enhanced catalytic activity [33,34]. Besides, Pt specie can activate interface oxygen species between Pt specie and WO3 in Pt/WO3 catalyst for propane oxidation [35]. The effect of Pt nanoparticles size has also attracted much attention, Ge et al. found that the size of Pt nanoparticles on CeO2 (100) significantly affects the charge of Pt specie, which is closely related to the catalytic performance of propane oxidation [36]. To optimize the activity of Pt based catalyst, there is urgent to develop more strategies to modify the Pt species nature for efficiently catalyze propane oxidation. Herein, we present an novel strategy to regulate geometric and electronic structure of Pt species in Pt/SiO2 model catalyst for efficient propane oxidation. In this work, we adopted photo-deposition and ultra-low loading Mo promoter modification to change the nature of Pt species. It is found that Mo promoter can decreases the Pt particles size and donates electron to Pt particle. Additionally, photo-deposition Pt particle on SiO2 surface also benefits to more Pt0 specie generation compared to wetness impregnation method. This structured metallic Pt species is more stable than those obtained by H2 reduction. Results of activity evaluation, C3H8-TPSR and kinetic experiments suggest that photo-deposition Pt species and Mo modification remarkably promotes the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst for propane activation, which is ascribed to nature change of Pt active sites favoring rate determined step first C-H activation. Therefore, this work conducted a systematic study of geometric and electronic structure effects of Pt species for propane oxidation. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Pt/SiO2 catalyst was synthesized using wetness impregnation method. Briefly, 1 g SiO2 support was dispersed into deionized water (5 mL), then H2PtCl6 solution (0.002 gPt mL−1, 5 mL) was dropped into above mixture at room temperature and stirred for two hours. Afterwards, the mixture was evaporated at 90 °C to power, and the yellow power was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, the power was calcined in a muffle furance at 500 °C for 4 h, with heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. To obtain the Pt/SiO2-R catalyst, the Pt/SiO2 catalyst was reduced in pure H2 flow of 10 mL min−1 at 200 °C for 1 hour. The Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by stepwise impregnation method. (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O precursor was dissolved in an anhydrous oxalic acid solution (with a molar ratio of oxalicacid to (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O = 2) and SiO2 support was added into the solution. After calcination at 500 °C, sample of 0.1Mo/SiO2 was obtained. Then Pt specie was supported by the same method of the Pt/SiO2 catalyst to prepare the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst. The Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P and Pt/SiO2-P catalysts were prepared using photo-deposition method. In typical, 1 g of support (0.1Mo/SiO2 or SiO2) was dispersed into deionized water (20 mL) by magnetic stirrer (800 rpm) for 10 min. Then desired amount of H2PtCl6 solution (1 wt% Pt loading) and 5 mL of methanol solution (as reducing agent) was added into the above solution. The mixture was stirred and irradiated by a 300 W xenon lamp with a magnetic stirrer (800 rpm) for 4 h. Solid sample was obtained by centrifuging, followed by drying at 60 °C for 12 h and calcination at 500 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface areas of catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption at −196 °C on a BK 200 C apparatus and calculated using Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method. Prior the test, the catalyst was degassed for four hours at 100 °C to remove the residuals in the pores and channels. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with the Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 40 mA in 2θ range of 10–90° with a scan speed of 12° min−1. Raman spectra were recorded by a confocal microprobe Raman system (Renishaw inVia Reflex) with an excitation laser of 325 nm (laser power =10 mW, dwell time = 60 s, number of scans = 100, resolution =1 cm−1). High resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images of the catalysts were obtained on a JEOL-2100 F microscope operated at 200 kV. CO chemisorption was carried out on a BELCAT II analyzer to measure the Pt dispersion. Prior the test, the catalyst was reduced under a mixture gas flow (5 %H2/N2 balanced, 30 mL min−1) at 150 °C for one hour. Afterwards, the flow of CO mixture (5 %CO/N2 balanced) was pulsed into the analyzer to determine the CO chemisorption uptake. The Pt dispersion was calculated by CO uptake with the assumption of CO: Pt=1:1. To analyze the surface Pt species, X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded in an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument equipped with Al Kα source (hv= 1484.6 eV) operated at 15 kV. Binding energies of all elements were calibrated by the containment carbon (C1s = 284.8 eV). For the C3H8 temperature-programmed surface reaction (C3H8-TPSR), 100 mg of catalyst is heated from 25 to 500 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min− 1 in a mixture flow of 30 mL min−1 (0.2 vol% C3H8/N2 balanced or 0.2 vol% C3H8 + 2 vol% O2/N2 balanced). The components in outlet gas were detected by a mass spectrometer Hiden HPR-20 R&D, and MS signals at m/z = 16, 29, 30 and 44 are collected for detecting CH4, C3H8, C2H6, and CO2, respectively. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of propane oxidation was carried out on a ThermalFischer Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory. Prior to the test, the catalyst put into a PIKE DRIFT accessory is treated in an N2 atmosphere at 250 °C for 30 min to remove the residuals in catalyst surface, and background spectra were recorded. Afterwards, a mixture flow (0.2 vol% C3H8 + 2 vol% O2 /N2 balanced, 30 mL min−1) was went into the equipment for 60 min at 220 °C, followed by pure N2 flow (30 mL min−1) for 60 min and the spectra were recorded. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The catalyst activity test was carried out in a lab-made tubular quartz reactor (i.d. = 6 mm). Prior the test, the catalyst need to be compressed and sieved (60–80 mesh). Then, 50 mg of catalyst was put into the quartz reactor. The propane mixture gas (0.2 vol%C3H8 + 2 vol%O2/N2 balanced, 66.66 mL min–1) went through the reactor (mass space velocity of 80 000 mL g–1 h–1). The reactor was heated to 500 °C from room temperature with heating rate of 10 °C min−1, then the temperature was gradually cooled down to the desired temperature for activity test. Propane concentrations in the inlet ([C]in) and outlet ([C]out) gas were determined using a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatography equipped with a HPGS-GASPRO capillary column and FID detector. The specific formula to calculate the propane conversion is given in following: Propane conversion = ([C]in - [C]out)/[C]in × 100% 2.4 Catalytic reaction kinetics Kinetic experiments of four representative catalysts of Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-P and Pt/SiO2 catalysts were conducted at differential reaction condition (with propane conversion below 15 %). The catalyst was diluted with quartz sand (with same size) to 60 mg, and it was aged under the same condition as in catalytic test. By adjusting the partial pressures of propane (0.202–0.808 kPa) and O2 (9.09–1.515 kPa) in the reaction gas, a series of reaction rates were obtained and related kinetic parameters were derived. The detailed data of Arrhenius plots are also given for calculating apparent activation energy (Ea). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 General characterization The morphologies of as-prepared Pt/SiO2-P, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalysts were investigated by HRTEM images ( Fig. 1). It can be found that Pt particles are successfully loaded on the surface of SiO2 support by different preparation methods. For the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, the Pt particle has a large mean size of 49.8 nm, which is obviously larger than those also prepared by wetness impregnation using Pt(NO3)2 precursor, [37] this result suggests precursor affecting the size of Pt nanoparticles. It is interesting to find that ultra-low Mo promoter on SiO2 benefits to disperse the Pt specie as the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst has slightly smaller Pt particles of 34.7 nm compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. Besides, the preparation method also affects the Pt particle size, the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst prepared by photo-deposition has smaller Pt species particle size of 39.1 nm compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. The Mo promoter also decreases the Pt particles size prepared by photo-deposition, the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst shows Pt particle average size of 28.7 nm. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns and Raman spectra of Pt/SiO2-P, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalysts. A broad peak centered at 20° is assigned to the amorphous SiO2 support [38]. While the characteristic diffraction peaks at 39.7, 46.2, and 67.7°correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) facets of the metallic Pt species (JCPDS No. 04–0802), respectively [39]. These peaks are observed for all these catalysts, suggesting large size of Pt species in the catalysts. This result is consistent with the results of TEM images. No diffraction peak assigned to MoOx species appears in the XRD patterns due to its ultra-low loading (0.1 wt % Mo). Raman spectra shows the vibration peaks at 493 and 971 cm−1 which are attributed to the D1 and D2 defective modes of tri-cyclotrisiloxane and the terminal Si-OH vibration, respectively [40]. The vibration peak ascribed to Pt is also absent in the spectra due to its low loading (1 wt%). Table 1 summaries the physicochemical properties parameters of catalysts. These catalysts show a comparable specific surface areas (330–350 m2 gcat −1) due to porous structure of SiO2. The actual contents of Pt and Mo in the catalysts are close to the nominal value as shown in Table 1. CO chemisorption tests were conducted to measure the amount of exposed Pt atoms based on the assumption of CO/Pt=1, and the average size of Pt particles has also been calculated by the CO chemisorption capacity. The difference of Pt particles average size between particle size statistics in TEM images and CO chemisorption is ascribed to the different assumptions in two calculation methods, but the tendency of Pt particles average size in these catalysts is unchanged for two calculation methods. For instance, it is found that the Pt/SiO2 catalyst has the lowest CO capacity and largest Pt particle size of 62.3 nm measured by CO chemisorption among all these catalysts. In order to study the chemical state of surface Pt species, the Pt 4 f XPS spectra were measured as shown in Fig. 3, Figure S1 and Figure S2. The XPS spectra can be deconvoluted into six components. For the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-P catalysts, the component with binding energy of 74.4 eV is attributed to the Pt 4 f 5/2 of the Pt0 specie; the component with binding energy of 75.0 eV is assigned to the Pt 4 f 5/2 of Pt2+ specie; while the signal corresponding to Pt 4 f 5/2 of Pt4+ specie appears at binding energy of 76.7 eV, respectively [33,41,42]. Certainly, the Pt 4 f XPS spectra of Pt species shifts to lower binding energy due to the addition Mo promoter, for instance, the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst shows Pt 4 f 5/2 of the Pt0 specie at binding energy of 74.3 eV. The binding energy of Pt 4 f XPS spectra of photo-deposited Pt nanoparticle on SiO2 surface further shifts to lower binding energy as shown in Fig. 5. The above results suggest the possibility of electron transfer from Mo to Pt species, thus the Pt 4 f XPS spectra of electron rich Pt species shifts lower binding energy. Yoshida et al. also reported the electronegative MoOx promoter improves the oxidation resistance of the metallic Pt species in the oxidation reaction atmosphere, suggesting the electron interaction between Pt and Mo.21 Besides, the proportion of surface Pt with different chemical sate has been analyzed and the percentage of Pt0, Pt2+ and Pt4+ is given in Fig. 3. Mo promoter increases the proportion of Pt0 specie, the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst shows higher proportion of Pt0 specie compared to that of Pt/SiO2 (34.8 % vs 26.2 %). Interestingly, photo-deposited Pt nanoparticle significantly leads to more Pt0 generation compared to which prepared by wetness impregnation method, as confirmed by Pt/SiO2-P in comparison with Pt/SiO2. More importantly, metallic Pt species in photo-deposited Pt nanoparticle has higher oxidation-resistance compared to those obtained by H2 reduction, which is confirmed by the Pt/SiO2-R catalyst having less proportion of metallic Pt (29.2 %) after exposure into air (Figure S1). Due to photo-deposition and addition Mo promoter simultaneously employed, the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst has the highest Pt0 proportion of 42.8 %. The above results confirm that electron transfer from Mo specie to Pt and more Pt0 specie forms because of Mo addition and photo-deposition method employed. 3.2 Catalytic propane oxidation Fig. 4a shows the light-off curves of propane complete oxidation oxidation over the Pt/SiO2, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-P and Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalysts. For comparison, the activity of pre-reduced Pt/SiO2 catalyst (Pt/SiO2-R) was also evaluated for propane reaction. The Pt/SiO2 catalyst exhibits the lowest catalytic activity for propane oxidation among all these catalyst, which may be ascribed to its lowest Pt dispersion and proportion of metallic Pt. The Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst shows a superior propane oxidation activity compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, mass specific rate of the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst (2.28 mmol gcat −1 h−1) is three folds increase compared to the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst (0.57 mmol gcat −1 h−1) at 200 °C, suggesting the significant promotion of Mo promoter, even in ultra-low loading. The Pt/SiO2-P catalyst obtained by photo-deposition method is significantly improved compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. Such result indicates photo-deposition Pt nanoparticle method remarkably affects the nature of Pt active sites, thus enhancing the catalytic performance. The catalytic performance was further increased by addition Mo promoter in the photo-deposition prepared Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst. It is well known that Pt species chemical state (metallic or oxidized Pt specie) significantly affects the catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of the Pt/SiO2-R catalyst was slightly increased which may be ascribed to the increase of metallic Pt species by reduction, however, the low oxidation-resistance of metallic Pt species obtained by H2 reduction resulted in proportion of metallic Pt species only slight increase. The propane oxidation activity of these catalyst is in order of Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P (2.28 mmol gcat −1 h−1)＞Pt/SiO2-P (0.57 mmol gcat −1 h−1)＞Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 (0.35 mmol gcat −1 h−1)＞Pt/SiO2 (0.16 mmol gcat −1 h−1). To study the change of Pt active intrinsic activity, the TOFPt of these catalysts were measured at 200 °C and listed in Table 1. It can be found that the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst shows the highest TOFPt of 357 × 10−3 s−1 for propane oxidation, which is much higher than other catalysts. Furthermore, the stabilities of Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P, Pt/SiO2-P, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts for propane combustion were also evaluated in Fig. 4b, all these catalysts show robust activity for propane oxidation. According to the CO chemical adsorption (Table S6), the Pt particle average sizes of the spent catalysts nearly remained same to the fresh catalysts, suggesting the stable structure of active sites in these catalysts prepared by different methods. Previous works confirms that oxidized Pt species were partially reduced to metallic Pt species during propane oxidation reaction.33 The Pt 4 f XPS spectrum of representative catalyst of spent Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P was analyzed (Figure S2), the proportion of metallic Pt species in catalyst indeed increases after propane oxidation, which is ascribed to the PtOx reduced by propane or its oxidation intermediate products. In order to study the different behaviors of surface reaction on these catalysts, C3H8-TPSR experiments were carried out as shown in Fig. 5. The mass spectrometry (MS) signals of C3H8, C2H6, CO2 and CH4 were recorded for m/z = 29, 30, 44 and 16. For the oxygen-involving C3H8-TPSR profiles (Fig. 5a-c), it can be found that the representative catalysts of Pt/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-P and Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P present very different C3H8 MS signal profiles during TPSR. The Pt/SiO2-P catalyst exhibits a reduced reaction onset temperature of propane oxidation at 245 °C, representing an approximate decrease of 50 °C compared to that observed for the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. Besides, the temperature windows (ΔT) of onset temperature to complete oxidation temperature are also very different for the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-P catalysts. A narrower ΔT is observed for the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst in comparison with the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, implying that propane oxidation rate on the Pt/SiO2-P surface rapidly increases when reaction temperature increased. CH4 MS signal ascribed to propane dissociation is observed for the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst at 254 °C but absent for the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, such result confirms the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst possesses much higher propane activation ability than the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, which is closely related to the different natures of Pt species in the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-P catalysts. For the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst, the reaction onset temperature of propane oxidation further decreases to 225 °C, and a narrowest temperature window of 50 °C is observed. And the CH4 MS signal appears at 239 °C, which is much lower than that of the Pt/SiO2-P catalyst. This result confirms that ultra-low loading Mo promoter on the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst further enhances the propane activation and oxidation. For the oxygen-free C3H8-TPSR profiles (Fig. 5d), MS signals of C3H8 and CH4 are unchanged in the test temperature range, such result suggests that the presence of gaseous oxygen plays critical roles on propane activation over the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst, the activated oxygen specie promotes the propane activation and dissociation. Fig. 6 shows the in-situ DRIFT spectra of propane oxidation over Pt/SiO2, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-P and Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalysts at 250 °C to further study the surface reaction. For the Pt/SiO2 catalyst under propane flow without O2, the vibration peak at 2975 cm−1 is ascribed to the C-H bond of gaseous propane [43,44]. The appearance of weak vibration peak at 2015 cm−1 assigned to CO bridged adsorption on Pt sites confirms the propane reacting with active surface oxygen species of the Pt/SiO2 catalyst without gaseous O2 participation,33 the weak vibration peak of CO2 appearing at 2339 cm−1 also implies the occurrence of oxidation reaction. The Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 catalyst also prepared by wetness impregnation method shows stronger vibration peak intensity corresponding to CO species, suggesting more surface active oxygen in the Mo promoter modified Pt/SiO2 catalyst. In contrast, the CO vibration peak is absent but the stronger CO2 vibration peak is found for the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst. This result indicates the faster propane oxidation reaction occurring with active surface oxygen species of the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst. It is found that the spectra changed when the flow switched to C3H8 + O2. A band centered at 1472 cm−1 is observed for the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-P catalysts, which is attributed to carboxylate species, the intermediates of propane oxidation [45,46]. The decreased intensity of carboxylate species vibration peak is observed on the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst, which may be ascribed to the fast decomposition of carboxylate intermediates on the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst. And the carboxylate species intermediates can be completely removed by N2 purge. Therefore, the pathway of propane oxidation on the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst can be described as shown in Scheme 2. Namely, propane is firstly activated and dissociated to hydrocarbons on Pt species. Afterwards, the hydrocarbons are oxidized to CO, which transforms to carboxylate species. The carboxylate species intermediates decompose to CO2. 3.3 Kinetic result Kinetic experiments were conducted to study the differences in catalytic behavior of the representative catalysts of Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P, Pt/SiO2-P, Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2, and Pt/SiO2 (Fig. 6). The related derived power law rate expressions of the overall propane oxidation reaction are summarized in the Table 2, namely, r = k [PC3H8]a [PO2]b, k is apparent rate constant, a and b are the rate orders of propane and oxygen, respectively. It can be seen that all these catalysts show the propane reaction order close to 1, which is consistent with the fact that propane molecule usually weakly adsorbs on the catalyst surface. Thus, the weak adsorption of stable saturated alkane on active site is one reasons for its difficult catalytic elimination. These catalysts shows activity decrease with the increasing oxygen partial pressure, suggesting the negative reaction order of oxygen. This result is ascribed to that gaseous oxygen strongly adsorbs on active sites and presents a competitive adsorption to propane molecule. The high value of oxygen negative reaction order indicates the seriously competitive adsorption to propane, which is not beneficial to the propane oxidation. It can be found that both the two strategies of addition Mo or photo-deposition Pt particles on SiO2 could weaken the oxygen competitive adsorption to propane, which may be one reason to enhance the catalytic activity. The apparent activation energies of these catalysts are also evaluated as given in Fig. 6c, which is in order of Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P (83.1 kJ mol−1) ＞ Pt/SiO2-P (113.9 kJ mol−1) ＞ Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2 (139.4 kJ mol−1) ＞ Pt/SiO2 (154.6 kJ mol−1). Apparent activation energy represents the catalyst ability for propane activation, which is closely related to the active sites state. C-H activation is usually regarded as the rate determined step in propane oxidation, and metallic Pt specie in the catalyst plays critical role on C-H activation. Addition Mo or photo-deposition Pt particles on SiO2 adjusts the Pt chemical sate, leading to more Pt0 specie generation as discussed in XPS spectra (Fig. 5). Therefore, the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst with most Pt0 specie shows the lowest apparent activation energy and highest catalytic activity for propane oxidation. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of SiO2 supported Pt catalysts have been prepared by wetness impregnation and photo-deposition methods, and the effect of ultra-low loading Mo promoter (0.1 % wt.) was also discussed. It is found that large size Pt particle generates on SiO2 surface due to the precursor H2PtCl6 used. Ultra-low loading Mo promoter can decrease the Pt particles size and transfer electron to Pt particle, which is confirmed by CO chemical adsorption, TEM and XPS results. Furthermore, photo-deposited Pt particles on SiO2 surface results in more Pt0 specie generation. Namely, the nature of Pt active sites are obviously modulated by photo-deposition and ultra-low loading Mo promoter. The Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst with more Pt0 specie shows superior catalytic activity for propane oxidation, ascribed to Pt0 specie favoring C-H bond activation (rate determined step of propane combustion), and gaseous oxygen promotes propane cleavage on active sites. This work provides a novel strategy to adjust the geometric and electronic structure of Pt particles to optimize the catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: The geometric and electronic structure of Pt active sites plays a crucial role in determining the catalysts performance, but precise regulation remains challenging. Herein, we propose a novel approach to modulate the nature of Pt active sites by combining photo-deposition of Pt nanoparticles with ultra-low Mo loading (0.1 wt%) modification on Pt/SiO2 catalysts. The addition of ultra-low loading Mo promoter not only effectively reduces the size of Pt particles but also donates electrons to the Pt particles. Furthermore, the photo-deposited Pt particles exhibit a higher proportion of metallic Pt species, which is more stable than that metallic Pt species obtained by H2 reduction, compared to those prepared using traditional wetness impregnation methods. Propane oxidation activity evaluations confirm that the photo-deposited and Mo-modified Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst exhibits the highest activity among all the prepared catalysts. Combined with experiments of C3H8-TPSR and in-situ DRIFT spectra of propane oxidation, it is found that the Pt/0.1Mo/SiO2-P catalyst remarkably promotes propane activation and C-H bond cleavage due to the nature change of Pt active sites, and the presence of gaseous oxygen benefits propane cleavage on active sites. Our primary results provide a promising strategy for designing superior platinum catalysts by regulating Pt active sites nature for efficient propane complete oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Novel strategy to regulate the geometric and electronic structure of Pt catalyst for efficient propane combustion
